questions.stem: A licensed clinical psychologist who specializes in cognitive-behavioral therapy for anxiety disorders receives a referral for a 7-year-old child with selective mutism. The psychologist has extensive experience with adults but has never worked with children and has no training in developmental psychopathology or child assessment. According to Standard 2.01 (Boundaries of Competence), the psychologist should:

options.text: Accept the case because CBT principles are applicable across age groups and the psychologist can learn as they go
Accept the case but read several articles on selective mutism before the first session
Decline the referral and refer to a psychologist with demonstrated competence in child clinical psychology
Accept the case and consult with a child psychologist after each session

questions.explanation: Standard 2.01(a) requires psychologists to provide services only within the boundaries of their competence, based on education, training, supervised experience, consultation, study, or professional experience. Working with a 7-year-old with selective mutism requires specialized knowledge in child development, child psychopathology, age-appropriate assessment, and child-specific therapeutic techniques that differ substantially from adult CBT. Self-study alone (B) is insufficient for a specialization this distant from the psychologist's training. While consultation (D) can sometimes supplement competence in adjacent areas, this case represents a completely new population and set of clinical skills. The most ethical action is to refer to a qualified child specialist. Accepting the case with minimal preparation risks harm to the child client.

questions.stem: During a severe natural disaster, a psychologist who specializes in industrial-organizational psychology encounters a survivor who is experiencing acute distress, suicidal ideation, and dissociative symptoms. No mental health providers with clinical training are available in the immediate area. According to Standard 2.02 (Providing Services in Emergencies), the psychologist should:

options.text: Refuse to provide any services because crisis intervention is outside their area of competence
Provide crisis intervention services to ensure they are not denied, and continue providing services indefinitely as long as the client wants them
Provide crisis intervention services to ensure they are not denied, but discontinue or refer once a qualified provider becomes available
Provide comprehensive psychotherapy for the dissociative symptoms since the emergency creates a blanket exemption from competence requirements

questions.explanation: Standard 2.02 permits psychologists to provide emergency services outside their usual competence to ensure that services are not denied. However, this provision is explicitly temporary -- services should be provided only until an appropriately qualified provider becomes available. Option A fails to recognize the emergency exception. Option B incorrectly extends the emergency provision indefinitely; the standard requires transition to a qualified provider when possible. Option D incorrectly characterizes the emergency provision as a blanket exemption; it permits only immediate crisis services, not comprehensive treatment for complex conditions. The I/O psychologist should stabilize the individual, address the immediate crisis, and arrange for appropriate clinical care as soon as it becomes available.

questions.stem: A psychologist earned their doctorate 15 years ago and has been practicing cognitive-behavioral therapy for depression. They have not attended any continuing education workshops, read current research, or updated their clinical skills since graduation. A new client presents with treatment-resistant depression, and the psychologist is unaware of significant advances in the treatment of this condition. This situation most directly implicates which standard?

options.text: Standard 2.01 (Boundaries of Competence), because the psychologist is now practicing outside their current competence
Standard 2.03 (Maintaining Competence), because the psychologist has failed to maintain adequate ongoing professional development
Standard 2.04 (Bases for Scientific and Professional Judgments), because the psychologist is not basing judgments on current scientific knowledge
Standard 2.06 (Personal Problems and Conflicts), because the psychologist may have lost motivation for professional development

questions.explanation: Standard 2.03 specifically requires psychologists to undertake ongoing efforts to develop and maintain their competence. A psychologist who has not engaged in any continuing education, current research review, or skill updates for 15 years is in direct violation of this standard. While Standards 2.01 (A) and 2.04 (C) are also implicated (the psychologist may be effectively practicing outside current competence and not basing judgments on current science), Standard 2.03 is the most directly relevant because the core issue is the failure to maintain competence over time. Standard 2.06 (D) addresses personal problems and is not the primary concern here, though motivational issues might contribute to the failure to maintain competence.

questions.stem: A psychologist is asked to provide expert testimony in a child custody case regarding the best interests of the child. The psychologist has not personally evaluated the child, the parents, or any family members. The attorney asks the psychologist to base their testimony on a review of documents prepared by another evaluator. According to Standard 2.04 (Bases for Scientific and Professional Judgments), the psychologist should:

options.text: Provide the testimony based on the document review, noting any limitations, as long as the opinions are grounded in established scientific and professional knowledge
Provide the testimony without limitation because reviewing another evaluator's work is an acceptable alternative to direct evaluation
Refuse to provide any testimony because psychologists can never offer opinions without conducting their own evaluation
Provide the testimony but overstate the confidence in conclusions to provide the attorney with the strongest possible support

questions.explanation: Standard 2.04 requires psychologists to base their work on established scientific and professional knowledge of the discipline. A psychologist may provide expert testimony based on document review, provided they clearly articulate the basis and limitations of their opinions. Option B is incorrect because the psychologist must acknowledge the limitations of opinions based solely on document review versus direct evaluation. Option C is too restrictive; psychologists can offer opinions based on document review in forensic contexts when they appropriately limit the scope of their conclusions. Option D violates both Standard 2.04 (basing judgments on science) and Standard 9.01 (appropriate assessment bases). The key is ensuring opinions are grounded in science and that limitations are clearly communicated.

questions.stem: A psychologist in private practice delegates the administration and scoring of psychological tests to a psychology technician. The technician has a bachelor's degree in psychology but has received no specific training in test administration. The psychologist reviews the results and writes the reports. According to Standard 2.05 (Delegation of Work to Others), this arrangement is:

options.text: Acceptable because the psychologist reviews all results and maintains responsibility for the reports
Unacceptable because delegation of psychological testing to non-doctoral personnel is never permitted under any circumstances
Unacceptable because the psychologist has not ensured that the delegated person has the necessary competence to perform the tasks, based on training, education, or experience
Acceptable because bachelor's-level personnel are always qualified to administer and score standardized tests

questions.explanation: Standard 2.05 states that psychologists who delegate work to employees, supervisees, or research or teaching assistants take reasonable steps to ensure that such persons (1) are authorized to provide the services by law, regulation, or organizational rule; and (2) have the competence to perform the tasks delegated, whether through education, training, or experience. In this case, the technician has received no specific training in test administration, which means the psychologist has not met the requirement to ensure the delegate's competence. Option A ignores the training requirement. Option B is too restrictive; delegation is permitted with proper training and supervision. Option D incorrectly assumes a bachelor's degree alone qualifies someone for test administration without specific training.

questions.stem: Standard 2.01 (Boundaries of Competence) identifies several legitimate bases upon which psychologists may claim competence. Which of the following are recognized bases for competence under this standard? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Education
Training
Supervised experience
Number of years in independent practice
Consultation, study, or professional experience

questions.explanation: Standard 2.01(a) specifically lists the recognized bases for competence: education, training, supervised experience, consultation, study, or professional experience. These represent multiple pathways through which psychologists can develop and demonstrate competence. Option D (number of years in practice) is notably absent from this list. Simply practicing for many years does not, in itself, establish competence in a given area, particularly if the psychologist has not engaged in relevant training or kept up with developments in the field. Competence is determined by the quality and relevance of one's preparation, not merely its duration.

questions.stem: A psychologist is considering expanding their practice to serve clients from a cultural and linguistic background with which they have limited experience. Standard 2.01(b) addresses competence when working with diverse populations. Which of the following steps would be consistent with Standard 2.01(b)? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Obtaining education, training, or supervised experience in working with the specific population
Consulting with colleagues who have established competence with the target population
Assuming that clinical skills are universally applicable and no specialized preparation is needed
Making appropriate referrals when the psychologist cannot develop adequate competence
Studying relevant cultural literature and attending multicultural competence workshops

questions.explanation: Standard 2.01(b) states that when psychologists are asked to provide services to individuals for whom appropriate mental health services are not otherwise available, psychologists with closely related prior training or experience may provide such services with appropriate study, training, consultation, or supervision. To develop competence with new populations, psychologists should obtain relevant education and training (A), consult with experienced colleagues (B), make referrals when competence cannot be adequately developed (D), and pursue cultural knowledge through study and workshops (E). Option C is inconsistent with the standard because it assumes clinical skills transfer universally across populations without adaptation, ignoring cultural factors that can significantly affect assessment, diagnosis, and treatment.

questions.stem: Standard 2.06 (Personal Problems and Conflicts) addresses situations where personal issues may interfere with professional functioning. Under which circumstances does this standard require psychologists to take action? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: When psychologists become aware that personal problems may interfere with their performing work-related duties competently
When psychologists know or should know that there is a reasonable likelihood that personal problems will prevent them from performing duties competently
Only when a formal complaint has been filed about the psychologist's impaired practice
When psychologists need to determine whether they should limit, suspend, or terminate their work-related duties
When personal problems have been reported by colleagues or clients

questions.explanation: Standard 2.06 has two key provisions: (a) psychologists refrain from initiating an activity when they know or should know that there is a substantial likelihood that personal problems will prevent them from performing competently; and (b) when psychologists become aware of personal problems that may interfere with their performing work-related duties adequately, they take appropriate measures such as obtaining professional consultation or assistance, and determine whether they should limit, suspend, or terminate their duties. The standard is proactive, not reactive -- it does not require a formal complaint (C) or reports from others (E) before the psychologist takes action. Self-awareness and self-monitoring are central requirements.

questions.stem: A psychologist is entering the emerging field of telepsychology, for which generally recognized standards for preparatory training do not yet fully exist. According to Standard 2.01(e) regarding emerging areas of practice, which obligations apply? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Take reasonable steps to ensure the competence of their work in the new area
Protect clients, students, supervisees, research participants, and organizational clients from harm
Wait until formal training programs in telepsychology are fully established before providing any services
Obtain relevant education, training, or consultation related to telehealth practices
Stay informed about developing professional guidelines and best practices in telepsychology

questions.explanation: Standard 2.01(e) addresses emerging areas where generally recognized training standards do not yet exist. Psychologists are not prohibited from practicing in these areas but must take reasonable steps to ensure competence (A) and protect those they serve from harm (B). This includes obtaining relevant education and training (D) and staying informed about developing guidelines (E). Waiting indefinitely for formal training programs (C) is not required and would leave clients without needed services. The standard recognizes that in emerging fields, psychologists must take proactive responsibility for their own competence development while the field establishes formal standards.

questions.stem: Standard 2.05 (Delegation of Work to Others) specifies requirements for psychologists who delegate professional tasks. Which of the following are requirements under this standard? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Take reasonable steps to authorize only persons who are legally permitted to perform the delegated services
Ensure that the delegated persons have the competence to perform the tasks based on their education, training, or experience
Delegate only to individuals who hold a doctoral degree in psychology
Maintain supervisory responsibility for delegated work, as the psychologist retains ultimate responsibility for the quality and appropriateness of the services
Avoid exploitative relationships with persons over whom they have supervisory or evaluative authority in the delegation process

questions.explanation: Standard 2.05 requires that psychologists who delegate ensure that delegates are (A) legally authorized and (B) competent for the tasks. Additionally, the psychologist maintains supervisory responsibility (D), consistent with the principle that the delegating psychologist retains accountability. Avoiding exploitation (E) is consistent with Standard 3.08. Option C is incorrect because delegation can appropriately occur to master's-level clinicians, psychology technicians, research assistants, and others, provided they have appropriate competence and authorization. The standard does not restrict delegation exclusively to doctoral-level personnel.

questions.stem: Match each Standard 2 subsection to the scenario it most directly addresses:

rows.text: A psychologist provides trauma debriefing to earthquake survivors despite having no trauma training, because no qualified providers are available
A psychologist going through a contentious divorce notices they are becoming increasingly hostile toward clients in marital therapy
A psychologist relies on a 20-year-old textbook as their sole reference for treatment recommendations, ignoring substantial new research
A psychologist allows an untrained office assistant to administer and score personality inventories

columns.text: Standard 2.05: Delegation of Work to Others

questions.explanation: Providing trauma services to disaster survivors without specialized training but in the absence of qualified providers is the emergency exception under Standard 2.02. A psychologist whose personal divorce is affecting their clinical work with marital therapy clients represents Standard 2.06, which requires self-monitoring and action when personal problems interfere with competence. Relying exclusively on outdated materials while ignoring current research violates Standard 2.03's requirement for ongoing competence maintenance. Allowing an untrained assistant to administer psychological tests violates Standard 2.05's requirements for ensuring delegates' competence.

questions.stem: Match each Standard 2 subsection to its core requirement or provision:

rows.text: Standard 2.04: Bases for Scientific and Professional Judgments

columns.text: Psychologists' work is based upon established scientific and professional knowledge of the discipline
Psychologists provide services only within areas defined by their education, training, supervised experience, consultation, study, or professional experience
Psychologists may provide services to ensure they are not denied, even when other standards cannot be met, until appropriate services become available
Psychologists refrain from initiating activities when personal problems may prevent competent performance and take measures to address such problems when they arise

questions.explanation: Each Standard 2 subsection has a distinct core requirement: Standard 2.01 defines competence boundaries through specific preparation pathways. Standard 2.02 creates a temporary exception allowing emergency services outside competence to prevent denial of services. Standard 2.04 requires that professional judgments be grounded in established science. Standard 2.06 mandates self-awareness and proactive management of personal problems that could impair professional functioning. These subsections work together to create a comprehensive framework ensuring that psychological services are delivered competently under both normal and exceptional circumstances.

questions.stem: For each Standard 2 subsection, select ALL circumstances under which the standard would be directly applicable:

columns.text: A psychologist with no forensic training is asked to conduct a competency-to-stand-trial evaluation
A psychologist encounters a suicidal individual at a community event where no crisis services are available
A psychologist recently diagnosed with major depression finds it increasingly difficult to concentrate during sessions
A psychologist trained in English-speaking populations is asked to provide services in a language they do not speak
A psychologist developing a substance use disorder begins missing appointments and making clinical errors

questions.explanation: Standard 2.01 applies when a psychologist is asked to practice outside their competence boundaries: conducting forensic evaluations without forensic training and providing services across a language barrier without appropriate linguistic competence. Standard 2.02 applies in the emergency scenario where a suicidal individual needs immediate help and no other providers are available -- this permits temporary services outside the psychologist's usual competence. Standard 2.06 applies to personal problems affecting professional functioning: major depression impairing concentration and substance use disorder causing missed appointments and clinical errors. Both conditions require the psychologist to take action to address the impairment.

questions.stem: For each approach to expanding competence, select ALL Standard 2 subsections that support or address it:

rows.text: Obtaining supervised experience in a new clinical area before practicing independently
Attending continuing education workshops on current evidence-based treatments
Basing clinical recommendations on peer-reviewed research rather than personal opinion

columns.text: Standard 2.04: Bases for Scientific and Professional Judgments

questions.explanation: Obtaining supervised experience before practicing independently directly relates to Standard 2.01, which lists supervised experience as one of the recognized bases for establishing competence in a new area. Continuing education workshops support both Standard 2.01 (as 'study' or 'training' contributing to competence in new areas) and Standard 2.03 (as a method for maintaining ongoing competence). Basing clinical recommendations on peer-reviewed research directly fulfills Standard 2.04's requirement that professional judgments be based on established scientific and professional knowledge of the discipline.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Standard 2.01 (Boundaries of Competence):

Psychologists provide services, teach, and conduct research with populations and in areas only within the [BLANK1] of their competence, based on their education, training, [BLANK2], consultation, study, or professional experience. When providing services to individuals whose [BLANK3] differ from those of the psychologist, psychologists obtain the training, experience, consultation, or supervision necessary to ensure competence. In [BLANK4] areas of practice where generally recognized standards for preparatory training do not yet exist, psychologists take [BLANK5] steps to ensure the competence of their work and to protect those with whom they work.

options: age, gender, race, ethnicity, culture, national origin, religion, sexual orientation, disability, language, or socioeconomic status
BLANK3.correct: age, gender, race, ethnicity, culture, national origin, religion, sexual orientation, disability, language, or socioeconomic status

questions.explanation: Standard 2.01 uses specific language that EPPP candidates must know precisely. Competence is defined by 'boundaries' (not scope or limits). The recognized bases include supervised experience specifically (not licensure or certification alone). The standard explicitly lists demographic and cultural factors including age, gender, race, ethnicity, culture, national origin, religion, sexual orientation, disability, language, and socioeconomic status. In 'emerging' areas, psychologists must take 'reasonable' steps -- not minimal or extraordinary, but reasonable steps to ensure competence. This precise language reflects the standard's balance between protecting the public and allowing the profession to evolve.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Standards 2.05 and 2.06:

When psychologists delegate work to employees, supervisees, or assistants, they take reasonable steps to ensure that such persons [BLANK1] to perform the services and have the [BLANK2] to perform the tasks based on their education, training, or experience. Separately, when psychologists become aware that [BLANK3] may interfere with their performing work-related duties adequately, they take appropriate measures such as obtaining professional [BLANK4] or assistance, and determine whether they should [BLANK5] their work-related duties.
questions.explanation: Standard 2.05 requires that delegates be 'authorized' (by law, regulation, or institutional policy) and have 'competence' (through training, education, or experience) to perform delegated tasks. These are distinct requirements -- authorization without competence, or competence without authorization, are both insufficient. Standard 2.06 specifically uses the term 'personal problems' and requires psychologists to obtain professional 'consultation or assistance' (not legal counsel or insurance) and determine whether they should 'limit, suspend, or terminate' their work-related duties. The escalating options (limit, then suspend, then terminate) provide a graduated response proportional to the severity of the impairment.

questions.stem: A psychologist has been treating adult clients with mood disorders for 20 years. Their practice has recently received increasing referrals for adolescents with eating disorders due to a shortage of providers in their rural community. The psychologist has no specific training in adolescent populations or eating disorders but feels pressure to accept these cases because clients have no other options within a reasonable distance.
questions.centerQuestion: Which Standard 2 provision most directly applies to this psychologist's decision?

options.text: The psychologist lacks training in adolescent development and eating disorder treatment
There are no other qualified providers available in the community
Eating disorders have the highest mortality rate of any psychiatric condition and require specialized intervention
The psychologist has extensive experience with mood disorders, which commonly co-occur with eating disorders
Pursue specific training in adolescent eating disorders before accepting referrals
Arrange for consultation and supervision with an eating disorder specialist
Accept all referrals immediately without additional preparation since some care is better than none
Explore telehealth options to connect adolescents with distant specialists while building competence

centerOptions.text: Standard 2.01(a): General boundaries of competence based on education and training
Standard 2.01(d): Services in areas closely related to prior training when appropriate services are otherwise unavailable
Standard 2.03: Maintaining competence through ongoing professional development

questions.explanation: Standard 2.01(d) specifically addresses situations where psychologists are asked to provide services to individuals for whom appropriate mental health services are not otherwise available. In such cases, psychologists with closely related prior training or experience may provide such services, but they must obtain the competence required through relevant study, training, consultation, or supervision. This is distinct from the emergency provision (2.02), which applies to acute crises, not ongoing service gaps. The psychologist should pursue specific training (R1), arrange for specialist consultation (R2), and explore telehealth alternatives (R4) while building competence. Simply accepting referrals without preparation (R3) would not meet the standard's requirements even when services are otherwise unavailable.

questions.stem: A psychologist who has been in practice for 10 years recently went through a painful divorce. Over the past three months, they have noticed increasing difficulty concentrating during sessions, irritability with clients who discuss relationship issues, and have begun canceling appointments at the last minute. A concerned colleague mentions that several clients have expressed dissatisfaction with the psychologist's recent behavior.
questions.centerQuestion: Which Standard 2 subsection is most directly relevant to this situation?

options.text: Difficulty concentrating during therapy sessions affecting clinical judgment
Emotional reactivity triggered by specific client content areas
Pattern of canceling appointments indicating functional impairment
Failure to complete required continuing education credits
Seek personal psychotherapy to address the impact of the divorce on professional functioning
Obtain professional consultation about whether and how to modify practice activities
Continue practicing without changes to demonstrate resilience
Determine whether to limit practice (e.g., not seeing relationship-focused cases) or temporarily suspend practice

centerOptions.text: Standard 2.05: Delegation of Work to Others

questions.explanation: Standard 2.06 (Personal Problems and Conflicts) directly addresses this situation. The psychologist's personal divorce is causing difficulty concentrating, emotional reactivity, and cancellation of appointments -- all clear indicators that personal problems are interfering with professional competence. Standard 2.06 requires the psychologist to: (1) be alert to signs that personal problems are affecting their work; (2) take appropriate measures such as obtaining professional consultation or assistance; and (3) determine whether to limit, suspend, or terminate work-related duties. Continuing practice without changes (R3) violates this standard. The psychologist should seek therapy, obtain consultation, and make necessary practice modifications.

questions.stem: A training director is developing a workshop on Standard 2 (Competence). Highlight the FOUR accurate statements about the competence standards:
questions.passage: (A) Standard 2.01 lists education, training, supervised experience, consultation, study, and professional experience as recognized bases for competence. (B) Standard 2.02 allows psychologists to provide services outside their competence in any situation where a client requests it. (C) Standard 2.03 requires psychologists to undertake ongoing efforts to develop and maintain their competence. (D) Standard 2.04 requires that psychologists' work be based on established scientific and professional knowledge. (E) Standard 2.05 prohibits all forms of delegation of psychological work to non-doctoral personnel. (F) Standard 2.06 requires psychologists to proactively monitor the impact of personal problems on their professional functioning. (G) The emergency provision in Standard 2.02 allows psychologists to practice indefinitely outside their competence once an emergency occurs. (H) Standard 2.04 requires psychologists to base their professional judgments on popular opinion and anecdotal clinical experience rather than established scientific knowledge.
questions.explanation: Accurate statements: (A) correctly lists the bases for competence in Standard 2.01; (C) correctly describes Standard 2.03's requirement for ongoing competence maintenance; (D) accurately represents Standard 2.04's scientific basis requirement; (F) correctly describes Standard 2.06's self-monitoring requirement. Inaccurate statements: (B) Standard 2.02 applies only to emergencies, not any client request; (E) Standard 2.05 permits delegation with appropriate training and authorization; (G) Standard 2.02 is explicitly temporary until appropriate services become available; (H) Standard 2.04 requires the opposite -- that judgments be based on established scientific and professional knowledge, not popular opinion or anecdotal experience.

questions.stem: Highlight the THREE scenarios that represent a clear violation of Standard 2 (Competence):
questions.passage: (A) A psychologist with expertise in forensic psychology conducts a comprehensive forensic evaluation within their area of specialization. (B) A psychologist who has never worked with children accepts a contract to provide play therapy services at an elementary school without obtaining any additional training. (C) A psychologist provides crisis intervention to a suicidal individual at a public event when no other mental health professional is available, despite not having formal crisis training. (D) A psychologist experiencing severe depression continues to see a full caseload of clients without seeking help or modifying their practice, even though their clinical judgment is visibly impaired. (E) A psychologist directs their unlicensed, untrained receptionist to administer, score, and interpret the MMPI-2 for all new clients. (F) A psychologist who has maintained competence through regular continuing education and consultation provides evidence-based treatment for PTSD using an approach they were trained in.
questions.explanation: Clear Standard 2 violations: (B) Accepting child therapy services without any child-related training violates Standard 2.01 (Boundaries of Competence). (D) Continuing full practice while severely depressed with impaired judgment violates Standard 2.06 (Personal Problems and Conflicts). (E) Directing an untrained receptionist to administer, score, AND interpret the MMPI-2 violates Standard 2.05 (Delegation of Work to Others). Non-violations: (A) Working within area of specialization is consistent with 2.01. (C) Providing emergency crisis services when no other provider is available is permitted under 2.02. (F) Maintaining competence and providing evidence-based treatment reflects compliance with Standards 2.03 and 2.04.

questions.stem: Arrange the six subsections of Standard 2 (Competence) in their correct numerical order:

options.text: Personal Problems and Conflicts
Maintaining Competence
Boundaries of Competence
Delegation of Work to Others
Providing Services in Emergencies
Bases for Scientific and Professional Judgments

questions.explanation: The six subsections of Standard 2 in correct order are: 2.01 Boundaries of Competence (establishing the foundational competence requirement), 2.02 Providing Services in Emergencies (the exception to 2.01), 2.03 Maintaining Competence (ongoing development), 2.04 Bases for Scientific and Professional Judgments (the evidence base for practice), 2.05 Delegation of Work to Others (extending competence through delegation), and 2.06 Personal Problems and Conflicts (threats to competence from personal issues). The progression is logical: define competence, provide the emergency exception, require maintenance, specify the evidence base, address delegation, and address personal impairment.

questions.stem: A psychologist is developing competence in a new clinical area. Arrange the steps in the most appropriate sequence from initial exploration to independent practice:

options.text: Begin supervised clinical practice with the new population under an experienced supervisor
Identify the specific competencies needed through consultation with experts in the area
Obtain formal education and training through coursework, workshops, or intensive training programs
Begin independent practice in the new area after demonstrating competence through supervision
Assess one's existing knowledge base and identify gaps relative to the new area of practice

questions.explanation: Developing competence in a new area follows a systematic sequence: First, conduct a self-assessment of existing knowledge to identify gaps (reflecting Standard 2.01's awareness of boundaries). Second, consult with experts to identify specific competency requirements. Third, obtain formal education and training to address identified gaps (consistent with Standard 2.01's recognized bases for competence). Fourth, begin supervised clinical practice to apply new knowledge under guidance (supervised experience being a recognized basis for competence). Finally, transition to independent practice after demonstrating competence through the supervised experience phase. This sequence ensures client protection while allowing the psychologist to systematically develop new areas of expertise.

questions.stem: Review the following data from a national survey tracking psychologists' self-reported competence concerns across practice areas over a 10-year period:

datasets.name: % reporting competence concerns about telehealth services
% reporting competence concerns about cultural/diversity factors
% reporting competence concerns about forensic practice

questions.question: What event most likely explains the dramatic spike in telehealth competence concerns between 2018 and 2020?

options.text: A new APA policy prohibiting telehealth practice
The COVID-19 pandemic forcing rapid adoption of telehealth services by psychologists who lacked prior telehealth training
A decline in technology availability
A reduction in the number of psychologists practicing telehealth

questions.question: The steady increase in cultural/diversity competence concerns likely reflects:

options.text: Psychologists becoming less culturally competent over time
Growing professional awareness and emphasis on the importance of cultural competence, leading to greater self-scrutiny under Standard 2.01(b)
A decrease in diverse client populations
Changes in the Ethics Code removing cultural competence requirements

questions.explanation: The data reveal significant trends in competence concerns: The telehealth spike from 30% to 65% between 2018-2020 clearly corresponds to the COVID-19 pandemic, which forced many psychologists to rapidly transition to telehealth services without adequate prior training, directly implicating Standard 2.01(e) on emerging areas. The steady increase in cultural competence concerns reflects the profession's growing emphasis on diversity, equity, and inclusion, consistent with Standard 2.01(b)'s requirements for competence with diverse populations. The decline in forensic concerns suggests increasing availability of forensic training programs. These patterns highlight how the competence standards apply dynamically as the practice landscape evolves.

questions.stem: A state licensing board tracks complaints related to Standard 2 (Competence) over several years, broken down by specific subsection:

questions.question: What pattern is evident in the impaired practitioner complaints, particularly the 2020-2021 spike?

options.text: The spike is random and has no identifiable cause
The pandemic's psychological toll on practitioners led to increased burnout, personal problems, and consequent impairment, consistent with Standard 2.06 concerns
Licensing boards changed their definition of impairment
Fewer psychologists were practicing, so complaints were proportionally higher

questions.question: The steady increase in delegation-related complaints most likely reflects:

options.text: A trend toward more psychologists using paraprofessionals and technology-assisted services without adequate competence assurance
A decrease in the number of trained support staff available
Licensing boards becoming less tolerant of delegation
All delegation of psychological services has become prohibited

questions.explanation: The data show important trends in competence-related complaints. The spike in impaired practitioner complaints during 2020-2021 coincides with the COVID-19 pandemic, which caused unprecedented levels of burnout, compassion fatigue, and personal distress among mental health professionals -- creating conditions under which Standard 2.06 became critically relevant. The steady increase in delegation complaints reflects expanding use of paraprofessionals, psychology technicians, and technology-assisted services (such as app-based interventions and AI-assisted screening) without adequate competence assurance under Standard 2.05. Practicing-outside-competence complaints remained the most common throughout, consistent with this being the foundational competence standard.

questions.stem: Categorize each scenario according to which Standard 2 subsection it most directly implicates:

items.text: A psychologist has not updated their knowledge of DSM diagnostic criteria since DSM-IV-TR, despite the publication of DSM-5 and DSM-5-TR
A school psychologist provides psychological first aid to students after a school shooting, despite having no formal crisis intervention training
A psychologist with expertise only in adult psychotherapy agrees to conduct a neuropsychological evaluation on a child
A psychologist experiencing chronic pain and taking opioid medications notices increasing cognitive difficulties during clinical work
A psychologist trained exclusively in individual therapy begins conducting group therapy without any additional training or supervision
A psychologist grieving the death of a family member begins crying during client sessions but takes no corrective action

questions.explanation: Standard 2.01 (Boundaries of Competence) is violated when psychologists practice in areas requiring distinct competencies they lack: conducting neuropsych evaluations without neuropsych training and conducting group therapy without group-specific training. Standard 2.02 (Emergencies) applies to the school psychologist providing immediate crisis response when no trained crisis professional is available -- this is the temporary emergency exception. Standard 2.03 (Maintaining Competence) is violated by failing to update diagnostic knowledge through multiple DSM revisions. Standard 2.06 (Personal Problems) is implicated by chronic pain-related cognitive difficulties and unaddressed grief reactions affecting sessions -- both require the psychologist to take proactive measures.

questions.stem: Categorize each professional development activity according to which Standard 2 requirement it best fulfills:

items.text: Attending an annual conference to stay current on treatment advances in one's specialty area
Completing a post-doctoral certificate program in a new clinical specialty
Regularly reviewing meta-analyses and systematic reviews relevant to one's treatment approaches
Obtaining supervised experience in neuropsychological assessment as part of a planned practice expansion
Participating in monthly case consultation groups with colleagues in one's specialty
Reviewing the empirical evidence base before recommending a specific intervention to a client
Completing required continuing education credits on topics within one's current practice areas
Enrolling in a specialized training program for EMDR therapy to add to one's therapeutic repertoire

questions.explanation: Developing new competence (Standard 2.01) involves activities that build skills in areas outside one's current practice: a post-doctoral certificate in a new specialty, supervised experience in neuropsychology, and specialized EMDR training. Maintaining existing competence (Standard 2.03) involves activities that keep current skills sharp: attending conferences in one's specialty, case consultation within one's area, and continuing education in current practice areas. Strengthening the scientific basis (Standard 2.04) involves activities focused on evidence and science: reviewing meta-analyses and systematic reviews, and reviewing empirical evidence before making treatment recommendations. These categories overlap in practice but represent distinct ethical obligations.
